sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Computerized axial tomography: individual technique, area(s) examined, and equipment will determine the suspension quantity and concentration to be used
  • Computerized axial tomography: Prepcat(R), total bowel opacification: 300 mL ORALLY the evening prior to examination, 300 mL ORALLY 2 hours prior to exam, and 300 mL ORALLY 15 minutes prior to exam
  • Computerized axial tomography: Prepcat(R), upper GI opacification: 300 mL ORALLY 2 hours prior to CT scan, then 300 mL ORALLY 15 minutes prior to CT scan
  • Computerized axial tomography: Volumen(TM), 900 to 1350 mL ORALLY beginning 20 to 30 min prior to procedure; for enhanced gastric marking, the final 200 mL should be taken immediately prior to scan; to enhance bowel lumen marking increase up to 1800 mL ORALLY
  • Computerized axial tomography: Volumen(TM), problematic marking (obesity, delayed transit), increase total volume up to 1800 mL ORALLY
  • Endoscopy of esophagus: Bar-Test(TM), 10 grain tablet ORALLY with 1 or 2 swallows of water just prior to fluoroscopic exam by esophagoscope
  • Gastrointestinal investigation: product used, individual technique, area(s) examined, and equipment will determine the suspension quantity and concentration to be used
  • Gastrointestinal investigation: Barosperse(R), double contrast colon examination: 400 mL of a 110% w/v suspension ORALLY
  • Gastrointestinal investigation: Barosperse(R), esophagus swallow: 2 to 3 teaspoonfuls (225 grams of Barosperse(R) mixed with 75 mL of water) ORALLY; for distensibility and peristaltic motion study, use 110% w/v suspension ORALLY
  • Gastrointestinal investigation: Barosperse(R), filled colon examination: 2000 mL of a 25% w/v suspension RECTALLY or 2500 mL of a 17% w/v suspension RECTALLY
  • Gastrointestinal investigation: Barosperse(R), small bowel examination: 240 to 480 mL of a 85% w/v suspension ORALLY
  • Gastrointestinal investigation: Barosperse(R), upper GI series: 75 mL of a 110% w/v suspension ORALLY followed by 195 mL of an 85% w/v suspension ORALLY
  • Gastrointestinal investigation: Barosperse(R), upper GI series plus small bowel examination: 75 mL of a 110% w/v suspension ORALLY followed by 240 mL of an 85% w/v suspension ORALLY
  • Gastrointestinal investigation: Volumen(TM), 900 to 1350 mL ORALLY beginning 20 to 30 min prior to procedure; for enhanced gastric marking, the final 200 mL should be taken immediately prior to scan; to enhance bowel lumen marking increase up to 1800 mL ORALLY
  • Gastrointestinal investigation: Volumen(TM), problematic marking (obesity, delayed transit), increase total volume up to 1800 mL ORALLY
  • Radiography of intestine: individual technique, area(s) examined, and equipment, will determine the suspension quantity and concentration to be used, caution to not overfill the colon
  • Radiography of intestine: Volumen(TM), 900 to 1350 mL ORALLY beginning 20 to 30 min prior to procedure; to enhance bowel lumen marking increase up to 1800 mL ORALLY
  • Radiography of intestine: Volumen(TM), problematic marking (obesity, delayed transit), increase total volume up to 1800 mL ORALLY

  • Gastrointestinal investigation: quantity of suspension and concentration dependent on patient size, technique used, and clinical need

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Computerized axial tomography
  • Endoscopy of esophagus
  • Gastrointestinal investigation
  • Radiography of intestine

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• colon obstruction, known or suspected
  • distal small bowel obstruction, suspected
  • duodenal or jejunal obstruction, complete, in newborns
  • gastrointestinal tract leakage, possibility of (eg, necrotizing enterocolitis, unexplained pneumoperitoneum, gasless abdomen, other bowel perforation, esophageal perforation, or postoperative anastomosis), in infants and young children
  • gastrointestinal tract perforation, known or suspected
  • hypersensitivity to barium sulfate or any product component
  • latex allergy or hypersensitivity; balloon retention enema tips contain latex
  • obstructing lesions of the small intestine
  • procedures requiring small volumes of contrast media in very small preterm infants or young babies
  • pyloric stenosis
  • rectal biopsy, recent
  • rectum inflammation or neoplastic lesions
  • swallowing disorders in infants
  • tracheoesophageal fistula, suspected

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• allergic reaction including anaphylaxis has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • previous reaction to a contrast agent
  • allergy, family history
  • atopy, as evidenced by hayfever and eczema
  • blind loops of the bowel or ileus; risk of inspissation leading to partial or complete obstruction
  • bronchial asthma, history
  • cardiac disease, advanced
  • catheter administration of large quantities; increased risk of aspiration
  • colon motility, reduced; post-procedure saline cathartics may be required
  • colostomy patient; examination requires a specially-designed enema tip
  • concomitant use of other oral agents; separate oral administration
  • constipation, history; routine saline cathartics are recommended unless clinically contraindicated
  • cranial pressure increased; risk of exacerbation
  • cystic fibrosis; risk of inspissation leading to partial or complete obstruction; obstruction of the small bowel (impaction) has been reported in pediatric patients
  • debilitated patients, severely
  • food aspiration, history (oral administration)
  • hypertension, marked
  • intussusception in neonates; increased risk of perforation
  • motility disorders such as Hirschsprung's disease (in infants or neonates); fluid overload has been reported due to absorption of water from the suspension
  • oral administration to an infant using a bottle; increased risk of aspiration and potentially-fatal cardiopulmonary arrest
  • vaginal or rectal intravasation resulting in death has been reported

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiorespiratory arrest, Edema
  • Gastrointestinal:Impaction of intestine, Small bowel obstruction
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction (rare)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Barium sulfate increases the absorption of x-rays as they pass through the body, thus delineating body structures, in which barium sulfate is localized.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Oral
    • shake well before using
    • Barosperse(R): administer within 6 hours of preparation and shake again just before patient administration
  • Rectal
    • shake well before using
    • Flo-coat(TM), shake vigorously for 30 seconds before using

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
BARIUM SULFATE
USES: Barium sulfate is used as an oral or rectal contrast agent in radiologic studies. In industry it is used as a lubricant, as a pigment in paints, and in manufacturing of cellophane, photographic papers, brake linings and adhesives. PHARMACOLOGY: Barium is used in radiologic procedures because it is radiopaque. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is very rare, exposure rarely causes significant adverse effects. TOXICITY: Barium sulfate is insoluble and not absorbed. Acute toxicity does not develop. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Constipation, impaction, obstruction, cramping, diarrhea, and rarely, appendicitis, bowel perforation, and peritonitis can occur. ECG abnormalities have been reported. Aspiration can cause pneumonitis, granulomas, and transient dyspnea and hypoxia. Venous intravasation can cause pulmonary emboli.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
BARIUM SULFATE
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Significant toxicity is not expected after ingestion, treatment is supportive. Treat mild allergic reactions with antihistamines and corticosteroids. Administer inhaled beta agonists and epinephrine for more severe reactions. Patients with aspiration may need bronchoscopy.
  • Decontamination: Barium sulfate is not absorbed, GI decontamination is not necessary. Irrigate exposed eyes with water.
  • Monitoring of patient: No specific laboratory studies are needed in most patients. Patients who aspirate barium or inhale barium dust should be followed with chest radiographs and pulmonary function testing.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: There is no role for hemodialysis or hemoperfusion.
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: Patients with inadvertent ingestions can be managed at home. Patients with deliberate ingestions should be sent to a medical facility for psychiatric evaluation. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients with significant aspiration, intravenous injection or peritoneal contamination with barium should be admitted. CONSULT CRITERIA: Consult a surgeon for any patient with suspected barium leakage into the peritoneum. Consult a pulmonologist for suspected barium aspiration.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
BARIUM SULFATE
A toxic dose has not been established. Barium sulfate is almost insoluble; systemic toxicity has not been reported after ingestion. Aspiration and intravenous administration may be fatal.
